posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We’ve always used 'flip down' style intakes. We did one 4-bar style intake, but it was chain driven and static so that when it was impacted it didn’t fold up.

I’m wondering – what’s the drive mechanism people use to allow a 4-bar style intake to fold up when hit, but still be able to verify when it’s down or up.

Here’s a screen shot of Poofs in 2022. Their intake was constantly hitting walls and other robots and folding up without damage. How do you actuate something like this with motors, but allow it to fold?

My initial thought would be to spring it down, and use something like one-way bearings and chain to actuate it up. But I don’t think that’s how the better teams are doing it.

posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked: I'm wondering what drive mechanism people use to allow a 4-bar style intake to fold up when hit but still be able to verify whether it's down or up. In this specific example, I'm pretty sure 254 used pneumatics, which would have actuated the mechanism back to the deployed state even after being forced back into a collapsed state. A good example might be to look at 1678’s robot from Rapid React, which I believe used a motorized pivot. Their system seemed to have a good amount of compliance built in, so they might not have had to compensate for the driven link being back-driven.

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: When PID is enabled for the pivot motor, current sensing allows the robot to maintain the intake in the "out" position. Once the current exceeds a set threshold, the system detects an obstacle and automatically pulls the intake inward. However, manually operating the intake into a hard stop while it's extended may cause issues.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: You can use encoder position to determine the system's state (up or down). Gain scheduling helps manage deployment, and a PID controller deploys normally. If stable, switch to an overdamped PID for smoother operation when force is applied.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Once the intake is turned off, the motor can function as a spring with minimal current input, provided the gear reductions aren’t weak. However, drawing out the free body diagram is more important here—understanding how much back-drive force you’ll encounter when interacting with obstacles. High-pivot 4-bar mechanisms, such as those we observed in 2022, were more prone to back-drive issues when interacting with walls due to the way forces propagated through them. Instead, consider alternative configurations, such as compliant or stretchy linkages, which would better suit protecting the intake under varying forces.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: My issue with using current sensing to do this is a couple folds. First, if I'm actuating this thing quickly, pretty often it's broken before the feedback of "too much current" is back and I can make a decision. Second, I hate fixing what I think is a mechanical problem in code. Fixing this issue in code is possible, but seems wrong to me: this is primarily a mechanical problem that feels like it should be addressed with design. Pneumatics is the easy way, but most people have removed pneumatics now and it seems like an elegant motor solution would be out there somewhere. I suppose some type of friction clutch would work as well—a couple pieces of stacked polycarb tensioned together, etc. Perhaps if you sprung the intake down, and pulled up with some dyneema.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Using the motor as a spring works well. It's an elegant solution. Can't get much less part count than zero.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: My issue with using current sensing to do this is a couple fold… I think you misunderstood. You set a low current limit so that the intake folds back in on itself when a force acts upon it. The super low current limit allows any hit to "overpower" the motor so it folds in.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: The description by @Enjsnake introduces some confusion. With a low hold current in the out position, the mechanism doesn’t require active retraction; instead, the force acting on it retracts the mechanism, overpowering the motor as described. When the force is removed, the mechanism pops back out. Once properly configured and the position set, the mechanism behaves passively and complyingly without any active actions or decisions being required.
Just wondering, will setting the motor’s neutral mode to coast when it is deployed work?

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked:
The use of current sensing to control an actuator presents challenges. Actuators fail before receiving feedback about excessive current, necessitating mechanical failure analysis. Fixing such issues in software is error-prone.

An additional safety layer is crucial for managing intake systems. An intake mechanism should withstand impacts without collapsing. A 2024 design successfully prevented collapse despite being smashed, demonstrating resilience.

Horizontal motion direction enhances intake stability. Force application varies with movement, requiring tuning for optimal resistance. Intake strength and linearity are key factors; ideal tunability ensures reliability under varying conditions.

Pneumatic options are less effective due to radial force distribution during operation. Motors offer better linearity, though voltage regulation remains critical. Applying consistent low voltage avoids abrupt openings, unlike sudden current limits.

Lastly, motor operation as a spring benefits from steady voltage, preventing rapid actuation beyond force thresholds. Consistent activation avoids mechanical stress, enhancing performance and longevity.

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked: Just wondering, will setting the motor’s neutral mode to coast when it is deployed work? If you are not running a PID or too strong of a voltage keeping it open, yes. If you have a PID, that will resist the movement nevertheless. But like I said on the previous reply, maybe just keep it in coast all the time and hold it up with PID then.

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked: The only thing to remember is to have the contact point with the wall above your main axis of rotation for the “driving” arm of the geometry, so it folds “up” instead of “down” and gets stuck. On our 2022 1678 copycat intake, we made the front axis movement entirely linear, which is even better. As long as the lower axis point on the front portion of the four-bar linkage is above that arm’s rotation point, you’ll have a collapsing mechanism. Limiting current and using a pretty fast gear ratio works well. We implemented this on Whisper and it worked perfectly. One of the few intakes we built that didn’t need any maintenance to function properly.

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked: Limiting current and putting in a pretty fast gear ratio works well. I’s what we did on Whisper and it worked out great. To keep it open, were you guys running a PID, relying on gravity, applying a small voltage or something else?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: So limiting current in that way might really slow down the motion of putting the intake out. Additionally, it appears that your intake linkage is directly aligned with the collision. Could it be that the intake lifts because your rollers impact the wall and raise it? Our intakes have been somewhat heavy historically, and I usually believe that more current equals more power and speed.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: A friction clutch system was tested, involving stacking polycarb materials under tension. Initial attempts included modifying intake components by cutting grooves and adjusting collars, utilizing common off-the-shelf parts (COTS). The clutch engaged through friction, allowing manual adjustment via an encoder and PID control, preventing damage in case of stall. While effective for many applications, its reliability depends on the intake arm's weight and resistance, suggesting it isn’t universally applicable.

link_counts.title: "Give a little" - keeping mechanisms from exploding on impact

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Serial elastomers are another valid option here, as someone mentioned in a related thread.  
You can do a lot with studs and springs.  
I’m going to stand by my stance that the geometry of the 4-bar linkage is the starting point and not how you’re powering it.  
Running a force perfectly in line down a link directly into a robot frame will never result in a collapsible intake.

posts.name: Andrew McBride
posts.cooked: Tom_Line mentioned that limiting current in that manner might slow down the intake motion. He added that you can adjust current limits dynamically during operation—setting them higher when actively moving the intake (e.g., 80A) and lower during stationary positions (10-15A).

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked: The system requires sufficient torque to function effectively. We utilized surgical tubing to elevate the mechanism. Additionally, the intake linkage does not align straight; instead, it pivots slightly, causing the mechanism to rise due to its lower axis of rotation, resulting in an angle under 180 degrees. This design ensures smoother operation despite having more components. An edit was made to correct a previous oversight.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: With different eco-systems, I remember some of those calls take longer than others and you want to avoid doing them repeatedly. I can’t remember (and didn’t see it immediately in phoenix 6) whether changing the current limits is one of those slower operations.
